bibl.title: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter, September 8, 1921

div1.p: Carter recommends continuation of work. He requests to stay since he is the most qualified. He fears a yellow fever outbreak in Lima.

div1.head: Memorandum from Henry Rose Carter, September 8, 1921
div1.p:
Referring to the last paragraph of Page 3 of your letter of Septem-
ber 8th., and what follows, I would say

1/ There is no question but that the work should be continued
until completed.

I think, I would feel reasonable sure, that if no fever shows
by Jan. 1st. that it is over--provided, of course, that a fairly good
medical inspection is kept up to that time in both the territory in
which the fever existed and in that which was exposed to infection
from that territory.

Still, I think both the Stegomyia control and medical inspection
had best--ought to--be--kept up until the end of this hot season. Frank-
ly, I would not feel safe unless this were done. You have had fever in
many places and in many of them not enough to immunize the population.
Likely enough it is now already eliminated and the risk after Dec. 31st.--
none showing--will be small, yet in my judgement too great to take. I
would strongly recommend then to continue Stegomyia control and medical
inspection to the beginning of the next cold season. It is possibly un-
necessary, but I don't think beyond the limits of reasonable insurance.

2/ You are clearly the agent best qualified to complete this work.
No man as suitable as yourself is available. You have handled the situa-
tion well: You know the whole of it, personal and local, but this doesn't
admit of argument.

I know how you desire to get back to the States, but having stayed
so long I judge you could stay to finish the job; and, maybe a smaller
thing and yet worth consideration, it will add to your reputation to
have completed the elimination--we trust the permanent elimination--of
yellow fever from the Pacific Coast of South America--no small thing to
claim, I should say.

3/ Either Trujillo or Lima would do for headquarters. I am in-
clined to favor the former as more central, but there are some advant-
ages in Lima. You could thus have Mrs. Hanson and the two youngest--
Carl going to school in the U. S., as you suggested. You would not be
much with them, but would see them, as Mrs. Carter used to say of me:
“Semi-occasionally.”

You can't reasonably expect fever to develope in any part of Lam-
bayeque north or east of Chiclayo and Lambayeque town--too well immu-
nized. You would have to watch from, and including, Chiclayo to Lima.

Lima is almost the only place I fear after Dec. 31st.--the summer
comes late in Lima. I don't think our Japanese from Ferranape infected
Lima. If so, it should have showed by last April. Also, I think that
a small amount of fever in Lima at the advent of the cold season would
most likely die out. The last epidemic lasted through 2 cold seasons,
but it was quite large before the cold season began. If it be in Lima
now, as everyone has yellow fever in mind, should it not show up by
Jan. 1st? I take it for granted that Lima could not reasonably expect
to get any from the North after--say--Sept. 15th.
